DataElement.preferredName: Pancreas Surgical Procedure System Complication Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term categories that represent the organ system affected or complication occurrence resulting from a pancreatic surgical procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Pancreas Surgical Procedure Complication Organ System
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known._A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery. An anatomical structure that consists of organs and organ subclasses responsible for certain body functions.  Representative examples are the gastrointestinal system, urinary system, and hematopoietic system._Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure._

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.:A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Concepts.definition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Property.preferredDefinition: An anatomical structure that consists of organs and organ subclasses responsible for certain body functions.  Representative examples are the gastrointestinal system, urinary system, and hematopoietic system.:Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

Concepts.definition: An anatomical structure that consists of organs and organ subclasses responsible for certain body functions.  Representative examples are the gastrointestinal system, urinary system, and hematopoietic system.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, Toronto, ON

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to the heart and the blood vessels or the circulation.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the heart and the blood vessels or the circulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A medical condition that develops at the site of an existing wound. Examples include swelling, draining, bleeding, formation of hematoma, infection, and necrosis.

Concepts.definition: A medical condition that develops at the site of an existing wound. Examples include swelling, draining, bleeding, formation of hematoma, infection, and necrosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The entire nerve apparatus, composed of a central part, the brain and spinal cord, and a peripheral part, the cranial and spinal nerves, autonomic ganglia, and plexuses.

Concepts.definition: The entire nerve apparatus, composed of a central part, the brain and spinal cord, and a peripheral part, the cranial and spinal nerves, autonomic ganglia, and plexuses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The system that includes the esophagus, stomach, small and large intestine, anus, liver, biliary tract, and pancreas.

Concepts.definition: The system that includes the esophagus, stomach, small and large intestine, anus, liver, biliary tract, and pancreas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (RES-pih-ra-tor-ee) The organs that are involved in breathing. These include the nose, throat, larynx, trachea, bronchi, and lungs.Also known as the respiratory tract.

Concepts.definition: The organs involved in the exchange of carbon dioxide and oxygen including the trachea, bronchi, and lung parenchyma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The organs involved in the creation and excretion of urine.

Concepts.definition: The organs involved in the creation and excretion of urine.
